name: Tbikha b'Tomatem (Chicken Tomato Stew)
name_origin: The name is purely Tunisian Arabic (Derja). 'Tbikha' derives from the Arabic triliteral root Ṭ-B-Kh (ط-ب-خ), meaning 'to cook.' In the Maghreb (Tunisia, Algeria, Libya), the noun form 'Tbikha' (طبيخة) specifically refers to a ragout or thick stew, distinct from a 'Marqa' (which implies a more liquid sauce). 'Tomatem' (طماطم) is the standard Tunisian word for tomato, ultimately derived from the Nahuatl 'tomatl' via Spanish and French. The construction 'b'Tomatem' uses the preposition 'bi' (with/in).
description: A rich, red Djerban stew featuring chicken and potatoes cooked in a deep sauce made from both fresh tomatoes and tomato paste. The sauce is thickened by a double-sautéing process typical of North African cooking.
cultural_context: A traditional Tunisian/Djerban dish. The technique of frying the tomato paste ('teklia') before adding water is essential to develop the deep flavor and color characteristic of this cuisine.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace chicken with chickpeas or white beans for a traditional vegetarian version.

steps.instruction: Heat oil in a pot and fry the 2 diced onions until translucent.
Add the paprika, followed immediately by the chopped fresh tomato and sliced green pepper. Season with salt and black pepper.
steps.tips: Adding the tomato quickly prevents the paprika from burning.

steps.instruction: Cover and let the mixture steam/sauté on low heat for about 10 minutes to soften the vegetables.
Add the tomato paste. Stir well and cook (steam) for another 10 minutes. This step removes the acidity from the paste.
Add water to cover, the cubed potatoes, and the chicken pieces. Bring to a boil.
Lower heat and simmer until the chicken is cooked through and the potatoes are tender.

name_etymology.notes: Standard Maghrebi culinary terminology. In Djerba and Libya, 'Tbikha' is the standard term for a main course stew eaten with bread, whereas in Algiers, 'Tbikha' often refers specifically to a vegetarian spring stew of peas and fava beans. The Djerban usage aligns closer to the Libyan usage.

alternative_names.name: Tbekha
alternative_names.notes: Common transliteration variant of the short vowel sound.

alternative_names.name: Marqa Batata
alternative_names.notes: While 'Tbikha' refers to the cooking style, if the dish is primarily potatoes and chicken, it may be colloquially called 'Marqa' (sauce) by non-Djerbans.

alternative_names.name: Tbikha Hamra
alternative_names.notes: Meaning 'Red Stew,' a term used in neighboring Libya for similar tomato-based stews.

similar_dishes.name: Marqa
similar_dishes.similarity: A tomato-based stew with meat and vegetables.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Marqa is a broader term for any saucy dish; Tbikha often implies a thicker reduction or specific vegetable focus.

similar_dishes.name: Tbikha (Algerian)
similar_dishes.similarity: Shares the name and stewing method.
similar_dishes.key_difference: The famous Algerian Tbikha is usually vegetarian (fava beans, peas, artichokes), whereas the Djerban/Tunisian version features chicken or meat.

similar_dishes.name: Tagine Djeij b'Batata
similar_dishes.key_difference: Cooked in a conical clay tagine with less liquid; the spice profile uses ginger/saffron rather than the heavy tomato paste and paprika (harissa) base of the Tunisian version.

similar_dishes.name: Patates Yahnisi
similar_dishes.similarity: Chicken and potato stew with tomato base.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses Turkish salça (paste) but lacks the specific North African 'taqliya' (garlic/caraway/coriander) flavor base.

intro_paragraph: Tbikha b'Tomatem is a rich Tunisian vegetable stew. The word 'Tomatem' (תטמטם) is the Judeo-Tunisian word for tomatoes, reflecting the unique Hebrew dialect of Tunisian Jews. This slow-cooked dish features vegetables simmered in a thick, seasoned tomato sauce until tender and deeply flavored.

vegan_substitutions.notes: Provides a chewy, meaty texture that absorbs the sauce well
